Section 4(b) of Public Law 94-241 is amended to limit payments to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands for fiscal years 1996 and beyond to amounts specified in the Agreement of the Special Representatives on Future Federal Financial Assistance. Additional amounts not required for the payment schedule in the Agreement will be subject to Congressional approval. Additional funds will be allocated to the Secretary for obligation as specified. For fiscal year 1996, all additional amounts will be used for capital infrastructure projects in American Samoa. For fiscal years 1997 and beyond, the funds will be solely for capital infrastructure projects in Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Palau, Micronesia, and the Marshall Islands. $3 million will be allocated to the College of the Northern Marianas in 1997, and up to $3 million annually may be used for immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues in the Northern Mariana Islands. The Secretary of the Interior will develop a five-year plan for infrastructure assistance in the Northern Mariana Islands, focusing on immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues. The plan will prioritize projects, consider master plans, Corps of Engineers' recommendations, maintenance needs, and local cost-share requirements. The Secretary of the Interior will allocate funds for infrastructure projects in the Northern Mariana Islands, with a potential emergency fund of up to $2 million per year for disaster relief. Additional contributions may be made for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll, not exceeding $32 million from any Federal source after January 1, 1995. The President must approve contributions as a final settlement for US obligations to assist in resettling Rongelap Atoll. Federal agencies in the Marshall Islands can provide funds for resettlement through the Secretary of the Interior. Ex gratia assistance may be given under certain conditions, but no aid can be given until full resettlement funds are provided. The federal minimum wage is addressed in Section 2. The minimum wage provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act will apply to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, with a starting rate of $2.75 per hour, increasing annually until it reaches the federal minimum wage rate. The minimum wage rate for the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be aligned with the rate set in the Fair Labor Standards Act. The minimum wage rate for the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be aligned with the rate set in the Fair Labor Standards Act. SEC. 3. REPORT. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with other government officials, must report to Congress by March 15 each year on funds allocated for immigration, labor, and law enforcement activities in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The report includes immigration data, treatment of non-US citizen workers, foreign government interference, and the impact of local laws on federal interests. The Secretary of the Interior must report to Congress annually on various issues in the Northern Mariana Islands, including interference with workers' rights, the impact of local laws on federal interests, detention facility adequacy, alien identification system reliability, and challenges in enforcing federal laws without additional funding. SEC. 4. IMMIGRATION COOPERATION. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and the Immigration and Naturalization Service will work together to identify and potentially exclude or deport individuals posing security or law enforcement risks to the Commonwealth or the United States. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF LOCAL EMPLOYMENT IN THE MARIANAS. Section 8103(i) of title 46 of the United States Code is amended to allow aliens in the CNMI to work as unlicensed seamen on fishing vessels within US waters. The amendment also updates references in the code accordingly. SEC. 6 amends Public Law 93-435 to clarify ownership of submerged lands in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. References to the date of enactment in the law now refer to the date of enactment of this section. SEC. 7 requires an annual State of the Islands report. The Secretary of the Interior must provide an annual "State of the Islands" report to Congress on various territories, including economic development, federal assistance, local finances, infrastructure, and financial management. Additionally, a technical correction is made to amend a section regarding the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands.
